questions.text: Under the EU MDR, what is the reporting timeline for a serious incident that led to death?

options.explanation: 2 days is for serious public health threats, not individual death events.
Per Section 5.2, death or unanticipated serious deterioration of health must be reported within 10 calendar days under EU MDR.
15 days applies to other serious incidents.
30 days is the FDA MDR timeline, not the EU MDR timeline for death events.

questions.text: Within how many hours must a reportability assessment be documented after becoming aware of a potential event?

options.explanation: Per Section 5.1, the reportability assessment must be documented within 24 hours of becoming aware of the event.
5 business days is far too long for reportability assessment.

questions.text: If uncertain whether an event meets reportability criteria, the organization should wait for more information before deciding.
questions.explanation: Per Section 5.1, if uncertain, err on the side of reporting. An initial report can be submitted with available information, and follow-up reports provided as more information becomes available.

questions.text: Who must approve an advisory notice before distribution?

options.explanation: Advisory notices require Regulatory and Management approval.
Per Section 5.6, advisory notices are reviewed and approved by Regulatory and Management.
Quality alone cannot approve advisory notices.
Customer support distributes notices but does not approve them.

questions.text: Under FDA regulations (21 CFR Part 803), what is the standard reporting timeline for a device malfunction that could cause serious injury?

options.explanation: 5-day reports apply when there is awareness of similar events, not as the standard timeline.
15 days is an EU MDR timeline, not an FDA timeline.
Per Section 5.2, FDA MDR requires reporting of malfunctions that could cause death or serious injury within 30 calendar days.
60 days exceeds the FDA reporting requirement.
